title: Ukraine whistleblower asks not to testify to Congress in person to shield his identity
text:
Lawyers for the Ukraine whistleblower whose complaint sparked an impeachment inquiry into President Trump may not give testimony in person to protect his identity.

The CIA officer, who has not yet been named, has reportedly asked to submit written testimony to Congress instead of appearing in person in order to stay anonymous.

If the request is granted it would see the testimony given during a closed-door congressional hearing or submitted as a written document.

President Trump has been accused of trying to pressure Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky into helping dig up dirt on Democrat rival Joe Biden and his son by withholding millions of dollars in aid.

Attorney Mark Zaid (right) has worked to protect the identity of the Ukraine whistleblower at the heart of the Trump impeachment inquiry. He is pictured (above) during an unrelated case in March

President Donald Trump speaking on stage during a campaign rally at the Target Center in Minneapolis yesterday. A whistleblower complaint alleges the president tried to pressure Ukraine into investigating one of his political rivals

The allegations stem from a CIA officer who claimed to have heard the full phone call between Zelensky and Trump in which the US president was said to have asked Ukrainian authorities to investigate Hunter Biden's time on the board of a natural gas company in the country.

The White House released a redacted transcript of the call in which Trump asked Zelensky to get Ukrainian prosecutors to probe Hunter Biden's business dealings, but Trump denied there was any threat of holding back military aid.

Fears the whistleblower's safety could be put in jeopardy if he is publicly identified have so far led to his name being kept a closely guarded secret among lawyers and House Democrats familiar with his allegations.

The move shows his legal team's concern over the whistleblower's identity, according to the Wall Street Journal.

The president has previously gone after the whistleblower, identified by the New York Times as a CIA officer, and demanded the right to face his accuser.

The Washington Post reported that House Democrats may interview the whistleblower at an off-site location to protect their identity, amid concerns it could leak.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky speaking during his day-long media marathon at a Kiev food court in which he denied there was any 'blackmail' over the infamous call with Trump

Trump has accused the whistleblower of having ties to one of his political opponents

Mark Zaid, the lawyer who represents the anonymous whistleblower, said previously he was working to protect his client's identity.

He wrote on Twitter in September not long after the allegations came to light: 'We continue to work w/both parties in House & Senate and we understand all agree that protecting whistleblower's identity is paramount.

'Discussions continue to occur to coordinate & finalize logistics but no date/time has yet been set.'

According to reports the whistleblower has been detailed to the White House in the past and is said to have ties to Biden during his time as as vice president under the Obama administration.

The whistleblower has previously been identified as having a Democratic party affiliation.

An intelligence source said it is likely that the unnamed CIA analyst, who is clearly an expert on Ukraine issues, briefed Biden and may have even accompanied him on Air Force Two on one or more of the vice president's six visits to the country.

On Wednesday, attorneys for the CIA whistleblower issued a carefully-worded statement denying that the had a 'professional' link to a 2020 Democratic candidate, saying he is an apolitical civil servant.

His lawyers said they wanted to 'clarify some facts' and denied in a statement that the whistleblower made the complaint due to any political allegiance.

Biden is seen with then-President Barack Obama signing executive orders to close down the detention center at Guantanamo Bay Cuba in 2009. Source say that Biden worked closely with the CIA whistleblower while serving as vice president

Zaid wrote on Twitter in a string of tweets: 'Our client has never worked for or advised a political candidate, campaign, or party.

'Second, our client has spent their entire government career in apolitical, civil servant positions in the Executive Branch.

'Third, in these positions our client has come into contact with presidential candidates from both parties in their roles as elected officials – not as candidates.

'Fourth, the whistleblower voluntarily provided relevant career information to the ICIG in order to facilitate an assessment of the credibility of the complaint.

'Fifth, as a result, the ICIG concluded – as is well known – that the complaint was both urgent and credible.

'Finally, the whistleblower is not the story. To date, virtually every substantive allegation has been confirmed by other sources. For that reason the identity of the whistleblower is irrelevant.'
description: The CIA officer at the heart of the Trump impeachment inquiry, who has not yet been named, has reportedly asked to submit written testimony to Congress instead of appearing in person.
